#Text=Abraham ben Elijah of Vilna
#Text=Abraham ben Elijah of
#Text=Vilna
#Text=was a Jewish
#Text=Talmudist who lived in Lithuania .
#Text=There is some debate as to when he was born .
#Text=Some place his birth as early as 1749 , but more recent scholarship suggests he was actually born in 1766 .
#Text=He was born in Vilna and died there on December 14 , 1808 .
#Text=He was the son of Elijah , the Vilna Gaon , the most famous Talmudist of modern times .

#Text=He was educated under the supervision of his father , who was famous both for his opposition to both the Hasidic movement , and the dry scholasticism which dominated the rabbinic leadership of Poland at that time .

#Text=According to the custom of the time , he married at the age of twelve , but continued his studies in the Talmudic colleges in other cities , and after a few years returned home , where he completed his studies under his father .
#Text=Like his father , he never officiated as rabbi , but was a highly respected member of the Jewish community of Vilna , in which he held various offices .
#Text=Works
#Text=It was due to his father 's influence that he developed a literary activity of a far more scientific character than was usually found at that age or in that country .

#Text=Especially interested in the history of the old homiletical literature , he edited the Midrash Agadat Bereshit with a number of other mostly pseudepigraphic works of similar character ( Vilna , 1802 ) , adding valuable notes .
#Text=In the preface of this edition he makes the first known attempt to give a complete history of the midrashic literature .

#Text=A plagiarist , Jacob ben Naphtali Herz of Brody , reprinted this edition with the preface ( Zolkiev , 1804 ) , but was careful to omit the name of Elijah Gaon wherever the son had mentioned him .
#Text=He omitted , also , on the title-page the mention of Abraham of Vilna 's edition , referring only to the one which had been printed in Venice in 1618 .
#Text=This introduction was only part of his greater work , Rav Po'alim ( Of Many Works , published by Simon Chones , Warsaw , 1894 ) .
#Text=This book is an alphabetical index of all midrashim known to the author .
#Text=It seems that Abraham of Vilna believed literally in the statement that the eighty concubines of King Solomon ( Shir ha-Shirim Rabbah 6:8 ) meant eighty midrashim .
#Text=This is at least testified to by Samuel Luria in a letter to Simon Chones ( Rab Po'alim , p.9 ) .
#Text=The book , however , contains over one hundred and twenty midrashic works .
#Text=While Abraham of Vilna shows greater interest in literature and literary questions than is found among his contemporaries , he accepts traditional attributions of authorship .
#Text=He ascribes the Zohar to Shimon bar Yochai , in spite of the many arguments against its authenticity produced by various writers since the time of Abraham Zacuto .
#Text=He accepts that the book was not written down until generations after Bar Yochai 's death .
#Text=He also believed in the traditional attribution of the Pirke D ' Rabi Eliezer .
#Text=Secular knowledge
#Text=Abraham 's interest in secular knowledge , quite rare in his environment , is also manifest in the writing of a Hebrew geography , Gebulot Ereẓ , published anonymously ( Berlin , 1801 ) .
#Text=The book is , in fact , a translation of parts of George-Louis Leclerc de Buffon 's Histoire Naturelle . [ 1 ]
#Text=He edited Menahem Mendel 's index to the Zohar , Tamim Yaḥdaw , to which he added an introduction and notes ( Vilna , 1808 ) .

#Text=Of his numerous manuscripts which contained glosses to the Talmud , Midrash , Shulkan ' Aruk , and explanatory notes to his father 's works , a commentary on the introduction to the Tikkune Zohar ( Vilna , 1867 ) , a commentary on Psalms I-C באר אברהם ( Warsaw , 1887 ) , Sa'arat Eliyahu , exegetical notes and biographical data about his father ( Jerusalem , 1889 ) , and Targum Abraham , notes on Targum Onkelos ( Jerusalem , 1896 ) , have been published .
#Text=The last-mentioned were edited by his great-grandson Elijah , who calls himself Landau .
